coredata.dc:title: Effect of vibrational energy transfer on laser-induced desorption
coredata.dc:creator: Fain, B.
Lin, S.H.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
A theory of a desorption induced by an infrared laser is developed. The laser excites an anharmonic molecule to the first excited level and higher vibrational levels are achieved by intermolecular energy transfer. Once the molecule is excited to the higher levels it may desorb. It is shown that a frequency dependence of the yield from the Rth excited level is proportional to the Rth degree of the corresponding Lorentzian. The yield is proportional to the Rth degree of the laser field power and is saturated when the number of adsorbate monolayers is increasing.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 114, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 March 1985 EFFECT OF VIBRATIONAL ENERGY TRANSFER ON LASER-INDUCED DESORPTION B. FAIN Chemistry Department. Tel-Aviv University, Ramat Aviv 69978. Israel and S H. UN Department of Chemistry. Arizona State University. Tempe. AZ 85287, USA Received 22 October 1984; in final form 2 January 1985 A theory of a desorption induced by an infrared laser is developed. The laser excites an anharmonic molecule to the first evcited level and higher vibrational levels are achieved by mtennoleculai energy transfer. Once the molecu'.c; is ex- cited to the higher levels it may desorb. It is shown that a frequency dependence of the yield from the Rth excited level is proportional to the Rth degree of the corresponding Lorentzian. "niB yield is proportional to the Rth degree of the laser field power and is saturated when the number of adsorbate monolayers is increasing. I. Introduction Surface reactions play a great role in chemistry and particularly in chemical technology. The possibility of combining unique properties of both catalysts and lasers in order to drive reactions along selected synthetic routes may have very important technological applications. Laser radiation might selectively affect the desorption processes, change the molecular concentration at a surface, induce surface etching reactions, affect surface diffusion, possibly separate molecules by masses, and change catalytic properties of adsorbants. A laser-induced desorption belonging to this class of processes is the simplest one and may provide a good check of theoretical models. Visible and ultraviolet lasers can desorb adsorbates via electronic mechanisms while IR lasers stimulate the desorption by exciting vibrational degrees of freedom. This paper is concerned with the latter mechanism. Experimental and theoretical studies of the laser-induced desorption (and the whole area of laser-induced sur- face processes) have been reviewed by Chuang [ 1 ]. Important experimental work relating to desorption by resonant vibrational excitation was reported by Heidberg et al. [2 4], studying CH3F adsorbed on NaCI; and by Chuang [1,5], and Chuang and Seki [6] studying 5 H^, C^D^ N on KC1, Ag and Ni. The main results of these experi- ments are: (1) The desorption is stimulated at moderate intensities ="1 MW/cm2;(2) the desorption is resonant at the vibrational frequencies of the adsorbate;(3) the frequency dependence of the desorption yield is narrower than the absorption shape; (4) dependence of the desorption on laser intensity / is proportional to the power of the intensity /m with m ^ 2.8 [2 4] and 2.2 [I ]; and (5) desorption depends on surface coverage S. This quanti- ty 5 is defined as the number of monolayers of adsorbates, it may be a non-integer, i.e. a part of monolayer could be adsorbed. For C^HgN KCl the desorption yield increases non-linearly with 5' and is practically constant [1 ] for S > 30. A number of theoretical studies devoted to the problem of laser-induced desorption [7 13] have been publish- ed. In recent papers [14,15], we developed a density matrix method for treating laser-stimulated surface proces- ses. The aim of this work is to give a theoretical explanation of all features of laser-induced desorption. Notice none of these theoretical papers [7 13] explains the desorption dependence on surface coverage. As we show 0 009-2614/85/S 03.30 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. (North-Holland Physics Publishing Division) 497 Volume 114, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 March 1985 here, the theoretical description of the influence ofvibrational energy transfer on laser-induced desorption in our previous paper [15] enables us to explain the desorption dependence on the surface coverage. To our knowledge it is the First theoretical explanation of this effect. 2. Theory We adopt a model used in refs. [10,13,15]. A system consists of molecules adsorbed on a solid surface. In physisorption, we can envisage the adsorbed molecule to sit in the potential well Uy which represents the interac- tion between the molecule and solid. This potential well depends on a, the quantum number of the internal vibra- tion of a molecule. Quantized energy levels of the desorption mode corresponding to this potential well Uy can be described by quantum numbers Vy. Thus, each state of the system will be described by quantum numbers (..s.Uy, , bf^Vb,-, ;a) where/, k are coordinates of the adsorbed molecules, and a denotes the quantum numbers of all low-frequency modes including lattice modes of the host. We assume that the energy of the quantum of the intra- molecular vibration is much larger than those of the other two types ofvibrational modes, desorption mode and phonon modes. To be desorbed the molecule should be excited to some high level Ey. If this energy is degenerate with the con- tinuum of the desorption mode, say of ground potential well UQ, the molecule can be desorbed. The rate of de- sorption is then proportional to the probability of transition from the excited state Ey of intramolecular motion to the continuum of the desorption mode 0. The infrared laser can induce desorption provided it excites a mole- cule to high enough vibrational level Eg in order to break surface bonds. However, for most molecules with signifi- cant anharmonicity the consecutive Ai> = 1 ladder-climbing photoexcitation process is unpractical. Once the first vibrational level is excited (v = 0 -* 1) by resonant IR photons, the vibrational anharmonicity will necessitate a lower frequency for the absorption of a second photon for the u = 1 - 2 transition, and so on. Therefore a single- frequency process alone cannot be responsible for the excitation of higher vibrational levels. But if intermolecular energy transfer is taken into account higher vibrational levels may be excited via the following processes' hcJ AB(u=0)^ AB(u= 1), AB(y = 1) + AB(u = 1) ^ AB(i/ = 2) + AB(u = 0) , AB(u = 2) + AB(u = 1) ^ AB(u = 3) + AB(u = 0) , (1) and so on. These kinds of processes have been investigated experimentally [16 18] and theoretically [19 21]. In the context of laser-induced desorption such a mechanism was suggested by Chuang [1]. In our previous paper [15] master equations determining the time development of the probability p(R.) that the/th molecule is on the level Eff were derived: P(R}) = -[WR +W]p(Rf) -J^WR^^^ \p{R,,mk) -p(m,,Rk)} + D M^i.i^cfcP^-Ufr)- (2) Here, p(a.b^) is a pair distribution function giving the probability that the/th molecule is in state a and the fcth in state &, w^ is the vibrational relaxation rate from the Rth level and k^ is the desorption rate. In deriving this equation resonant energy transfer processes n^m, -^ m^n, (3) were taken into account, and Ws.m^-.m -R^ = ^m Rie.R m^ are the corresponding rate coefficients. The following non-resonant energy-transfer process "A:1/-^A-+1 Oy (4) 498 Volume 114, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 March 1985 was also included and H/n i.;n.+iq is the rate of this process. But due to fast resonant energy transfer which homogenizes the probability of the excitation of the second level, a desorption rate per one molecule equals k^fS. Discussion Now we summarize the results of the above theoretical consideration and compare them with the experimental features of laser-induced desorption listed in the first section. (1) Estimates of the intensities at which laser-induced desorption takes place were made in ref. [15]. It has been shown that quite moderate laser intensities m the MW cm"2 range can induce the desorption. (2) (4) According to (22) the desorption rate from the Rth level of the adsorbate is proportional to w^. On the other hand, as shown in ref. [15], the transition probability of excitation of the first level w is w o: [(d-E)2ffi2] IV%/[(^o - t^ (B^u)2] , (23) where (f^ is the dephasing rate constant (between states 1 and 0),d is the transition dipole moment and E is the laser field. Thus, using from (22) that Y^ cr w^ and the fact that intensity I oc | -|2 we obtain from (23) the proportionality of the desorption raie to YR ^ {W%/ t(o->io - ")2 + ("Wl }R (24) Therefore, the desorption rate is proportional to the power m of the intensity P" with m = R and it is resonant at the vibrational frequency of the adsorbate c^io, but with a narrower frequency dependence than a simple absorp- tion shape (23). It is worthwhile mentioning that the dependence (24) is similar to the R -photon transition for a harmonic molecule with equidistant energy levels though the whole derivation is made under the assumption of an anhannonic molecule [7]. (5) According to formula (22) the desorption rate depends on the number ofmonolayers of the adsorbates, FR ex k^SI(w^S + k^). ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: A theory of a desorption induced by an infrared laser is developed. The laser excites an anharmonic molecule to the first excited level and higher vibrational levels are achieved by intermolecular energy transfer. Once the molecule is excited to the higher levels it may desorb. It is shown that a frequency dependence of the yield from the Rth excited level is proportional to the Rth degree of the corresponding Lorentzian. The yield is proportional to the Rth degree of the laser field power and is saturated when the number of adsorbate monolayers is increasing.
